newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan hog epidemic spreads, slaughters imminent.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan hog epidemic spreads, slaughters imminent.

text.p: Taiwan on Friday said it would start slaughtering hogs plagued by highly contagious foot and mouth disease which has spread to 47 breeding centres on the island.
"We will start slaughtering all pigs at infected breeding farms," Lee Jen-chyuan, secretary-general of the Council of Agriculture, told reporters.
Local media estimated at least 50,000 hogs would be slaughtered at the 47 confirmed infected farms.
The agriculture council banned all pork exports on Thursday following the outbreak of the deadly foot and mouth disease in the island's large hog population.
The council estimated that Taiwan exported six million out of its 14 million hogs per year.

According to a council survey in 1994, the hog industry's net value stood at T$89 billion (US$3.24 billion), comprising 20 percent of Taiwan's farm production value and 60 percent of the livestock value.
The island, facing a daunting task in trying to eliminate the disease, would import two million doses of vaccines to combat the outbreak, the council said.
Taiwan Sugar, one of the island's major hog breeders, said many smaller hog breeders would be forced out of businesses.
"Smaller breeding farms will certainly have to try other agricultural products or go bankrupt," Taiwan Sugar director Stella Yuan said.
At least nine small breeders in southern Taiwan have declared they will close down on Friday, local media reported. --Taipei Newsroom (2-508-0815)
